answers.answer: An ultrasound of.....what?  Your carotids maybe?  Did he order this test after listening to your neck with his stethoscope?  If the blood rushing through those arteries sounds noisy to him (it's called a bruit) he could be checking for narrowing in the neck arteries that carry blood to the brain.It sounds like you are doing many things right these days, including regular doctor visits.  Continue to educate yourself about heart health and then try not to add too much anxiety about how risk laden your vessels are.  You only have control over so much.  You can't change your history or health.  Anxiety can easily counter some of the positive steps you take.  Relaxing and enjoying life today is a healty thing to do.IMHO, the frequent media blitzes (and drug commercials!!) that could help educate the masses, often miss their indented targets and end up causing over-concern in others who get repeatedly slammed over the head with info barrage.

question: I have had relatively high cholesterol (about 200). I have been taking statins for a couple years and my levels have lowered greatly. Now my doctor has recommended that I have an ultrasound test to determine if I have blockages. I guess I will have it done since he has recommended it, but it has me worried. Does the recommendation mean that I probably have blockages? I'm slightly overweight (6'4" 225 lbs though I have lost about 30 lbs in the past year), I have never smoked, I don't have diabetes, my blood pressure is normal. I have been doing the 10,000 step walking program for several years now and I do 5K walks frequently. I never have experienced any chest pains, numbness, etc. I am 52 years old and a male so that is a risk factor. If I do have blockages what are the prognosis for a healthy life going forward?
title: Referred for ultrasound
